p.s: Description of Arcobacter marinus sp. nov.
Arcobacter marinus (ma.ri′nus. L. masc. adj. marinus referring to the sea, from where the type strain was isolated).
Cells grow well under both aerobic and microaerobic conditions.
Cells are slightly curved rods, approximately 0.5–1.7 μm long and 0.1–0.3 μm wide.
Cells are Gram-negative and motile with a single polar flagellum.
After 3 days on MA plates at 37 °C, colonies are circular, convex, creamy white and approximately 1 mm in diameter.
After 3 days on SBA plates at 37 °C, colonies are irregular, umbonate, grey and approximately 4 mm in diameter.
Growth occurs at 10–40 °C (optimum 30–37 °C) and at pH 5.9–8.5 (optimum pH 7.0).
Growth occurs at NaCl concentrations of 1–9 % (w/v) (optimum 3–5 %).
Oxidase is produced, but catalase, urease, alkaline phosphatase and H2S are not.
Indoxyl acetate is hydrolysed but hippurate is not.
The dominant fatty acids are iso-C15 : 0 2-OH and/or C16 : 1ω7c, C16 : 0 and C18 : 1ω7c.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 28 mol%.
The type strain, CL-S1T (=KCCM 90072T =JCM 15502T), was isolated from seawater to which seaweeds and a starfish were added.
